item.title: How to manage Big tasks with pomodoro technique
item.description: “Big” for pomodoro is anything that does not fit into the standard 25 minutes. In practice it appears that almost all tasks initially are “Big”. Typically you would “divide and conquer” such things but this only works when the scope of the task is known ahead. So how to tackle it when it’s not? Make a plan to make a plan Usually what I do is I start a reasonably small pomodoro timer for just making a plan.

item.title: How to accomplish things you're not interested in
item.description: Motivation is a great thing. It helps to move mountains, make lemonade from the apples or build the snowman out of rain. Also it helps to perform your daily job. But when it’s gone, even Chuck Norris cannot help you to bring it back. The problem is that it can be gone in the middle of the day leaving you with a pile of work that you don’t want to do but you have to.

item.title: Getting started with FocusBit on Windows
Using pomodoro technique with FocusBit
item.description: What is the Pomodoro technique? Pomodoro is a time management technique for improving productivity. It was developed in Italy in 80s. It breaks down work into smaller tasks that can be done in 25-minute intervals, separated by short 5-minute breaks. During 25 minutes interval (called “pomodoro”) you should only work on the task you decided. In other words you should postpone checking social media and emails for when the break starts.

3. Open FocusBit Double-click AppImage file - you’re good to go.
